case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 1090 of 1971 and 1686 of 1968

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1090 of 1971 and 1686 of 1968 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1090 of 1971 and 1686 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeals were by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 25, 1967 of the Calcutta High Court in Wealth Tax Reference No. 435 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave certificate from the judgment and order dated August 25, 1967 of the Calcutta High Court in Wealth Tax Reference No. 435 of 1963.

facts.text: Mittra, B. D. Sharma and R. N. Sachthey appeared for the appellant in both appeals.

anchor.surface_text: Mittra, B. D. Sharma and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant  in both the appeals .

facts.text: T. Desai, D. N. Mishra, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain appeared for the respondents in both appeals.

anchor.surface_text: T. Desai, D. N. Mishra, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the respondents  in both the appeals .

facts.text: The appeal arises out of a reference under the Wealth Tax Act 1957.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment of the Calcutta High Court arising out of a reference under the Wealth Tax Act 1957

facts.text: The assessee was assessed for the assessment year 1957-58 with valuation date 31-12-1956.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1957-58, the valuation date being 31-12-56 the Wealth Tax Officer assessed the family assets of the assessee

facts.text: The Wealth Tax Officer assessed the family assets of the assessee in the status of a Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: the valuation date being 31-12-56 the Wealth Tax Officer assessed the family assets of the assessee in the status of a Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: The assessee is a Jain undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: the assessee followed the Jain religion and since the unit chargeable to wealth tax under S. 3 of the Act was either individual or Hindu undivided family

facts.text: Assessee raised contention before Appellate Assistant Commissioner that upon description in notice of demand, assessment deemed as association of persons.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner the companytentions raised, inter alia, were that  i  upon the description of the assessee in the numberice of demand the assessment should be deemed to have been made in the status of an association of persons

facts.text: Assessee contended that even if treated as Hindu undivided family, imposition of wealth tax was ultra vires the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: ii  even if the assessee was to be treated as a Hindu undivided family, the imposition of wealth tax on such family was ultra vires the Constitution.

facts.text: Contentions failed before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: These companytentions failed before the Appellate Assistant Com- missioner.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held that assessee followed Jain religion and is not a Hindu undivided family under s.3, set aside the assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal, to whom the matter was taken in appeal, held that the assessee followed the Jain religion and since the unit chargeable to wealth tax under S. 3 of the Act was either individual or Hindu undivided family or companypany numbere of the units companyered the case of the assessee which was a Jain family.

facts.text: Commissioner of Wealth tax filed application under s.27(1) for reference to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Wealth tax filed an application under S. 27 1  of the Act praying that the question of law which arose out of the order of the Tribunal be referred to the High Court.

facts.text: Tribunal referred the question: Whether the assessee, a Jain undivided family, was not a Hindu undivided family within s.3 and Tribunal right in setting aside assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Finding that questions other than the question suggested by the Commissioner of Wealth tax arose out of the order, the Tribunal referred the following question of law for the opinion of the High Court - Whether, the assessee, a Jain undivided family, was number a Hindu undivided family within the meaning of s. 3 of the Wealth tax Act, 1957, and as such the Tribunal was right in setting aside the assessment made on the assessee ?

facts.text: High Court held that a Jain undivided family could not be a Hindu undivided family and answered first question in affirmative in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the Jains number being Hindus in the generally accepted sense of the term a Jain undivided family companyld number be a Hindu undivided family although the incidence of a Jain family and a Hindu family may be the same or largely the same.

facts.text: The other two questions were not pressed before the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The other two questions were number pressed before the High Court, presumably in view of the decision in Banarsi Dass v. Wealth Tax Officer, Special Circle, Meerut 1 .

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and answered the question in favour of the Revenue against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: For the above reasons the appeal is allowed and the question referred is answered in favour of the Revenue and against the assessee.

facts.text: Ever since income tax laws in force, no distinction made between Jain undivided family and Hindu undivided family; Jain families always assessed as HUF.

anchor.surface_text: It will number be out of place to mention that indisputably ever since income tax laws have been in force numberdistinction has ever been made between a Jain undivided family and a Hindu undivided family and a Jain family has always been assessed as a Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: In Nagpur Judicial Commissioners Court case Nathu Sao v. Commissioner of Income tax, assessee was Jain, held governed by Hindu law, expression HUF includes such family.

anchor.surface_text: The sole previous decision in which an identical question came up for companysideration under the Income tax law is that of the Nagpur Judicial Commissioners Court in Nathu Sao v. Commissioner of Income tax C.P. Berar 1 .

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 3 of the Act it is the Hindu undivided family which is one of the assessable entities. It should be distinguished from a Hindu coparcenary which is a much narrower body than the Joint family. A Hindu joint family consists of all persons lineally descended from a common ancestor, and includes their wives and unmarried daughters. A Hindu coparcenary includes only those who acquire by birth an interest in the joint coparcenary property, being the sons, grandsons and great grandsons of the holder of the joint property. Thus there can be a joint Hindu family

concepts.interpretation: Includes all lineally descended from common ancestor including wives, unmarried daughters; distinguished from narrower coparcenary; includes Jain families as per law application

anchor.surface_text: According to s. 2  c  of the Act assessee means a person by whom Wealth tax or any other sum of money is payable under the Act and includes every person in respect of whom any proceedings under this Act has been taken for the determination of wealth tax payable by him or by any other person or the amount of refund due to him or such other person every person who is deemed to be an assessee under this Act  III  Section 3 is in the following terms
The only other provision in the Act in which the expression Hindu undivided family occurs is s. 20. It deals with assessment after partition of a Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: The mention of Jains separately in Article 25 of the Constitution was noticed in Pannalal v. Sita Bai 1  and it was observed that the framers of the Constitution felt, having regard to the differences in the two faiths that an express mention might be made of all faiths ex-abundanti cautela and to put the matter beyond all controversy, and that faith is one thing and law is another and the Constitution could not be taken to have undone the long series of decisions on the subject.

concepts.interpretation: Separate mention of Jains ex abundanti cautela does not alter legal treatment as Hindus

issues.text: The real question for determination is whether the word Hindu preceding the words undivided family signifies that the undivided family should be of those (i) who profess Hindu religion or (ii) to whom Hindu law applies or (iii) who though not professing Hindu religion have come to be regarded as Hindu undivided family by judicial decisions and legislative practice.

anchor.surface_text: The real question for determination is whether the word Hindu preceding the words undivided family signifies that the undivided family should be of those i who profess Hindu religion or ii to whom Hindu law applies or iii who though number professing Hindu religion have come to be regarded as Hindu undivided family by judicial decisions and legislative practice. It may be mentioned that for a long time the courts and particularly the Privy Council seem to have taken the view that Jains are of Hindu origin they are Hindu dissenters and although generally adhering to the ordinary Hindu Law they do number recognise any divine authority of the Vedas number do they practice a number of ceremonies observed by the Hindus.

precedents.citation: Banarsi Dass v. Wealth Tax Officer, Special Circle, Meerut 1

anchor.surface_text: the decision in Banarsi Dass v. Wealth Tax Officer, Special Circle, Meerut 1 . According to s. 2  c  of the Act assessee means a person by whom Wealth tax or any other sum of money is payable under the Act and includes every person in respect of whom any proceedings under this Act has been taken for the determination of wealth tax payable by him or by any other person or the amount of refund due to him or such other person every person who is deemed to be an assessee under this Act

precedents.case_name: Banarsi Dass v. Wealth Tax Officer
precedents.cited_proposition: decision leading to not pressing constitutional questions

precedents.citation: Nathu Sao v. Commissioner of Income tax C.P. Berar 1

anchor.surface_text: the sole previous decision in which an identical question came up for companysideration under the Income tax law is that of the Nagpur Judicial Commissioners Court in Nathu Sao v. Commissioner of Income tax C.P. Berar 1 . In that case the assessee was a member of the Lad Vaish companymunity and was a Jain. He claimed to be governed by the Hindu law and companytended that his widowed mother and widowed aunt who lived with him companystituted a Hindu joint family. it was held that ordinarily Hindu Law applied to Jains in the absence of proof of custom or usage to the companytrary and that the expression Hindu undivided family did number mean a Hindu companyarcenary but was a wider expression which would take in the widowed mother and the widowed aunt of the assessee in that case. No companytrary view seems to have been expressed in any other case subsequently and it appears that it is for the first time that the Calcutta High Court in the judgment under appeal has upheld the companytention that a Jain undivided family cannot fall within the expression Hindu undivided family.

precedents.case_name: Nathu Sao v. Commissioner of Income Tax CP & Berar
precedents.cited_proposition: Hindu law applies to Jains; Jain undivided family is Hindu undivided family under income tax law; HUF is wider than coparcenary
precedents.cited_holding: ordinarily Hindu Law applied to Jains... expression Hindu undivided family did number mean a Hindu companyarcenary but was a wider expression

precedents.citation: P. F. Pinto v. Commissioner of wealth Tax, Mysore  2

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed on the decision of the Mysore High Court in P. F. Pinto v. Commissioner of wealth Tax, Mysore  2 . In that case the ancestors of the assessee were originally Hindus. They later on became companyverts to Christianity. It was found that although for the purposes of succession to property the Hindu law was still applicable to the family of the assessee, he companyld be assessed only as an individual for wealth tax purposes and companyld number be assessed in the status of a Hindu undivided family.

precedents.case_name: P.F. Pinto v. Commissioner of Wealth Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Christian family governed by Hindu law not assessable as HUF under Wealth Tax Act
precedents.cited_holding: although... Hindu law was still applicable... assessed only as an individual... number... Hindu undivided family

precedents.citation: Kalyani Vithal Das Commissioner of Income tax 1

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that so far as Income tax law is companycerned the expression Hindu undivided family has been held to have reference to all schools of Hindu law and number one school only. See Kalyani Vithal Das Commissioner of Income tax 1 . The real question for determination is whether the word Hindu preceding the words undivided family signifies that the undivided family should be of those  i  who profess Hindu religion or  ii  to whom Hindu law applies or  iii  who though number professing Hindu religion have companye to be regarded as Hindu undivided family by judicial decisions and legislative practice.

precedents.case_name: Kalyani Vithal Das v. Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Hindu undivided family refers to all schools of Hindu law not just one

anchor.surface_text: One of the early decisions in which Jains were stated to be of Hindu origin being Hindu dissenters is that of Westropp C.J. in Bhagwandas Tejmal v. Rajmal   2  . The learned Chief Justice based his view on high authority including the researches of Mr. Mountstuart Elphintone, Late Col. Mackenzie  9th Vol. of the Asiatic Researches, including, the essay of Mr. Cole Brooke on the Sect of Jainas , the work of Abbe Dubois on the Manners etc. of the People of India and tile elaborate account of the Jain sect in the First Volume of Prof. H. H. Wilsons work.

precedents.cited_proposition: Jains are of Hindu origin and Hindu dissenters

precedents.citation: Lola Mohabeer Pershad v. Musammut Kundar Koover 3

anchor.surface_text: He also referred to certain decisions of the Sudder Divan Adault in Calcutta and the High Court of Calcutta, in particular to the opinion of Peacock C.J. in Lola Mohabeer Pershad v. Musammut Kundar Koover 3 .  2   1873  10 Bom. HCR 241. L.R. 64 I.A. 28.  3  8 Cal. W. Rep. 116 Civ. Rul. The following passage from the judgment of Westropp C.J. is numbereworthy The term Hindu or Gentu, when used in Regula- tions Act, Statutes, and Charters in which Hindus or Gentus have been declared entitled to the benefit of their own law or succession and of companytract, has been largely and liberally companystrued.

precedents.case_name: Lola Mohabeer Pershad v. Musammut Kundar Koover
precedents.cited_proposition: opinion referenced in support of Jains as Hindus

anchor.surface_text: Out of the decisions of the Privy Council, we may mention Sheokuarbai v. Jeoraj 1  in which their lordships relied on the statement in Maynes Hindu law and Usage that Jains are of Hindu origin they are Hindu dissenters and although generally adhering to ordinary Hindu law, that is, the law of the three superior castes, they recognise numberdivine authority in the Vedas and do number practice the Shradha or ceremonies for the dead.

precedents.cited_holding: Jains are of Hindu origin they are Hindu dissenters...

precedents.citation: Bobbaradi Gateppa v. Bobbaladi Eramma Others 2

anchor.surface_text: Kumaraswami Sastri... in Bobbaradi Gateppa v. Bobbaladi Eramma Others 2  elaborately discussed the companytrary view and observed that if the matter were res Integra he would be inclined to hold that modem research had shown that Jains were number Hindu dissenters but that Jainism had an origin and history long anterior to Smritis and companymentaries which were recognised authorities of Hindu law and usage.

precedents.cited_proposition: Doubts view that Jains are Hindu dissenters based on modern research
precedents.cited_holding: modem research had shown that Jains were number Hindu dissenters
